job_title: Member Of Technical Staff in Atlanta, GA
pros: Beautiful campus, Courtesy Scholarship (after a waiting period), lots of interesting events, good research environment, access to world class scholars. Interesting work in the smaller departments where there is much less bureaucracy.
cons: Heavily Bloated IT management structure. IT managers are non-technical and know very little about implementing technology commonly in use elsewhere (e.g. cloud). They are insecure around technically knowledgeable individuals.  There are way too many project managers and manager positions  in general. Excessive amounts of meetings that really don't lead to substantial conclusions. Beware that for most of the staff, meetings seem to be the primary measure of productivity. Not going to meetings is a big no no even if you know they won't be productive.

pros: Emory is filled with a diverse palate of wonderful people who really do good work for the university and in their lives. Of course there are "bastions of insanity" but there are also very good departments within the division of campus life and outside of it.
cons: As much as Emory touted their belief in life/work balance, there are several managers who do not believe in that. Even working from home one day a week, or trying to work a compressed work schedule ( in a non busy season) was frowned up. That sort of inflexibility and an unwillingness to meet their needs of their employees is tough to take! While there are always a few positions that won't be able to share in such options, it would be nice if managers tried to fight for their employees needs and found ways to meet them halfway. This would boost morale.

review_title: If you're fit for academia, Emory is an excellent place to work!
pros: The work environment at Emory is friendly, and working in higher education often affords more flexibility.  Emory offers very attractive benefits, including a courtesy scholarship if you want to take classes or enter a part-time degree program while you work.  There are also a number of short courses, especially for career and skill development, that are offered through Learning Services.  The Faculty and Staff Assistance program that offers a variety of useful support programs, even counseling, for free.  Emory is place with a solid reputation for excellence, which also makes it a great place to work!
cons: The downside of working in academics anywhere is that the compensation is lower (compared to our counterparts in corporations).  Also, Emory is big, so depending on where and who you work for, the "message from the top" doesn't always trickle down to those on the front lines.  In other words, it's sometimes difficult to understand the vision.

review_title: Your leader sets the tone and the quality of leaders at Emory varies wildly.
pros:
Business casual dress code.
Pay is better than many other area universities.
Good retirement benefits, as long as you contribute at least a little bit (1.5%) for the match.
Courtesy scholarship.
Willing to spend money on equipment and services to get big jobs done.
Health insurance is decent, but not as great as it once was.
cons:
Pay is decent for a university, but far below what you could get elsewhere.
Courtesy scholarship has no value if your supervisor won't let you take the time to use it.
Not willing to spend money on people - Little to no raises over the last 5 years.
Crippling lack of big picture vision in lower and mid level management.
Health insurance costs and co-pays increasing, choices for providers decreasing.
Parking is very limited and very expensive - unsubsidized. Mass transit options are a joke.
Staff have no input into the review process for their leaders so bad leaders are often immune to their own mistakes and good leaders may fall victim to bad leaders at higher levels of the organization.

job_title: Senior Research Scientist in Atlanta, GA
pros: Benefits are decent and the campus is well manicured.
cons:
Extremely toxic, bullying, harassment culture from managers who are inept and hired without qualification, as others have mentioned.  I worked for a year and left a phenomenal university to come here, only to discover that hiring of managers is done  without regard to actual qualifications.

I was harassed, had personal items stolen from my manager, name called, bullied, threatened, gas-lighted, and when I went to HR, they told me to deal with it.  They also used the same tactic, initially, pretending to be concerned, only to extract information to use it AGAINST you later. 

The benefits are not worth working here.  I have worked at top tier Institutions and the research here is subpar.  This is because management is full of unqualified personnel who seek to destroy the science due to their need to feel competent and validated.

HR doesn't protect employees, they have a hierarchy which first they protect PIs, then managers, etc.  They do this because they said this is the best way to protect the University reputation etc.  Management KNOWS this and take advantage of it.

review_title: It doesn't take a lot to succeede.
job_title: Applications Dev/Analyst, Senior in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great retirement and health care plans.  Dental plan is the worst plan I've ever had.
cons:
Emory is a very political organization.  Hirings and promotions are all done behind closed doors and seem to be based only on an individual's relationship to management and not their qualifications or achievements.  Job postings are frequently changed to fit the individual's skills and not the skills required for the job.  

The vast majority of management does not posess a degree, skills, or experience in the industry/field they are in charge of.  Most managers produce nothing, and serve only as a distribution point for work.  Information is rarely disseminated to employees, if at all.  

Employee reviews are a whitewash and have no determination on employee raises.  Raises are usually quite small, 3% max, and though are said to be based on performance, have no indication of this.   

Responsibility is also lacking at Emory.  Missing deadlines, wiping out an entire month of email are gone unnoticed and without repercussion.

review_title: Good on paper, pretty much atrocious in every other aspect.
pros: Lots of available jobs. Sometimes the SON puts on events for employees that includes food and wine.
cons:
Human resources only cares about the administration, if you have any problems (including harassment, bullying) they will tell you to keep your head down or risk being fired.
Animal testing is done on campus and many of the scientists doing animal research lack the skills to do this humanely or they simply don't care.
"Equal opportunity employment" only applies to minorities and veterans...actually had my supervisor tell me to specifically not hire a white person (even though they were the most qualified) because they wanted a "black female."

review_title: Great place and striving to be even better!
pros: Important and meaningful mission to improve the world through education. A top ethically driven research University in the Southeast. Very socially active and socially conscious University. A huge sustainability program include state of the art water recycling facilities and the second largest LEED certified building footprint of any University. Flexible work schedules.  Progressive array of employee learning opportunities, very mature Employee Assistance Program and WorkLife department. Many support programs to promote employee health.  A lot of employees stay for a career. The University like many workplaces is going to experience a lot retirements in the next 5-10 years. Lot's of potential for advancement.
cons: Work culture varies dramatically between Departments and Schools. Pockets of untrained managers who drive some employee turnover.  Too many senior level people who have outdated views of workplace flexibility.

review_title: Great place to work, student body makes life difficult
pros: I was a graduate intern at Emory for two years. I worked with a great team and had the opportunity to interact with faculty and staff throughout the campus. Most of the people I had the opportunity to work with were lovely and made the job really pleasant. I felt like I was given increasing responsibility and really enjoyed the level of trust and freedom I received from my supervisors, who are some of the most passionate and energized people I know.
cons: The most difficult part of my experience was interacting with the student body (a requirement for some of my work duties). To make a sweeping generalization, I found them to generally be egocentric and largely apathetic, probably suffering from rich private school syndrome. I have worked with public universities and have never had the same experience. Something to consider if you will be working directly with students full-time.

review_title: Emory has changed a lot in the last 5 years
pros: It was a good place for a long time.  I felt like I was doing something more than just building widgets for the public to buy.  Involved in making the world a little better and working with others who had a good attitude that went beyond just making money.  Open to change and a healthy balance between work and family life.
cons: Emory changed several years back.  A new President and CFO has made Emory more interested in the bottom line.  Seems to have affected the entire University not just my department.  Generally everyone seems nervous about their continued employment and the lack of good general management skills is really hurting entire University and Hospital

review_title: A Great Place for Early Career Growth, A Hard Place to Stay Long Term
job_title: Associate Director, Research Projects in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Great Job Security
Great Benefits
Generous Vacation/Sick Leave
Flexible Schedule if Needed
Tuition Reimbursement
Promotes Continued Learning
cons:
Most of the benefits package is of no use if not a family with kids
Antiquated compensation progression mired in inflexible administrative policies
Little incentive for working better than average (negligible financial reward for excellent work)
"Merit pay" often constrained by departmental budget, managers told to downgrade employee performance ratings regardless of actual employee performance
Degree valued over skill and experience in most cases

pros: Flexibility. Trust. Challenging work with brilliant people. Very collaborative and exciting environment. Belief in the value of good basic science research. Good pay, benefits. I’m a working parent and my management understands the reality of this. I am very grateful to work at Emory!
cons: Poor infrastructural support for research/in general. Infrastructure is in growth phase- sometimes hard to find someone to help or who can direct me to the right person. Some departments seem hindered by distinctly poor quality work forces. Parking off site and taking shuttle in and back is a typical down side to working in academia.

review_title: Not a long term company to work for unless you have a doctorate's degree
pros: Health insurance (not paid for by company), access to Emory doctors, 401k match (one of the best benefits), health care incentives
cons: No promotion ladder if you work at the Yerkes Field Station. I'm unsure if this applies to the Yerkes Main Station or Emory Main Campus. Health insurance is great but not paid for by the company. 3% raise if you exceed expectations. My biggest issue is salary - it is very difficult to work at Emory and live in the city of Atlanta. My experience and salary is significantly lower than the average salary of Atlanta residents in my age range. The department I work in works with fatal viruses every day.  $35k annually is not worth it. Even in the name of science.

job_title: Associate Director of Programs in Atlanta, GA
pros: If you really enjoy your job this is a good place to work.  The benefits are great, the learning environment is great.  It is located in a nice area.  And there are plenty of opportunities to advance throughout the university.
cons: Even though it is a private university there is still a lot of bureaucracy, which stifles the working environment.  This is allows for more political decisions rather than decisions that are made in the best interest of the mission and goals of the department and/or university.  Also, It seems teleworking and other work-life benefits are only allowed for a select few.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Surrounded by brilliant minds; pleasant university setting; endless opportunities for continuing education and certifications; flexible work schedule; an array of learning opportunities; access to resources; tuition benefit for employees and dependents; mentoring program; diversity; growth opportunities; chance to work with and meet people from many different disciplines and lines of work; Frequent visits by fascinating people like the Dalai Lama and Alice Walker.
cons: Commute; Atlanta traffic is a bear to navigate if you live outside of the perimeter. The best way, it seems, to get around it is to move closer to work, which I am not ready to do just yet.

pros: Emory tries to build your strengths and strongly encourages training in soft skills for technical workers.  They do a great job of creating understanding of team dynamics.  The hours are reasonable and they don't push to work unpaid overtime like some places I've worked in the past.  Overall I've been very happy working here.
cons: Culture seems a little strange sometimes.  In general it's a pretty supportive culture.  But there are some people that just don't respond via emails for whatever reason and overall people are more into having meetings rather than just using emails to respond to quick questions.  Just different then other places I've worked that were faster paced.  So good in the sense that there's not a lot of chaos and fire fighting.  But be prepared for a slower response to things as they are very process driven.

review_title: Emory has good benefits, connections, and pay but lacks a sense of community and collaboration among departments.
pros: Good benefits, particularly health insurance and a 6% matching of your retirement savings through their 403b plan. Annual reviews for promotion/pay raise eligibility. Friendly and intelligent faculty and staff throughout the University. Paid vacation and sick leave time accrues fairly quickly. This paid time off along with the various free health services offered to employees shows that Emory cares about work life balance. Beautiful campus.
cons: Horrible traffic around area, and expensive parking pass. If you're involved in research, outreach, or some type of work that would benefit collaboration, it's often difficult to get people to look beyond their own work and self interest to collaborate with you, share resources, etc. Departments do not always do a great job of keeping you up to date with what kinds of work others are doing.

job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Diversity is wonderful. It would be difficult to work here and not be open-minded; more companies should be this way. Benefits and compensation are competitive. Most of the people are good to work with.
cons: If you start as an administrative assistant, it's hard to advance beyond that. This was a complaint I heard from a lot of admins. HR talks about work/life balance and flexible schedules, but in the 15 years I worked there, I never had a manager who was comfortable with anything but Monday through Friday, 9:00 to 5:00 in the office. As an admin, 90% of my work could have been performed from home. Parking is also an issue - $650 per year and it's quite a walk from the parking decks. Summers in Atlanta can be extremely hot and humid and of course walking in the rain is never fun.

review_title: Great place to work, as long as you don't work for the Mathematics and Computer Science department.
pros: Emory is a large employer, and it's a very exciting place to be. Most of the departments (other than Math/CS) are managed by people who genuinely care about the educational mission.
cons: The Math and Computer Science department is managed by people who are both incompetent and discriminatory regarding health issues. They outright refused to comply with or even acknowledge the medical conditions of employees, and often seemed to act with a malice towards employees that was sadly reminiscent of scenes in Office Space. Note that the scores here reflect this department; other departments likely deserve higher scores, but the university deserves blame for supporting this behavior.

review_title: Strong leadership and clear strategic plan made work at Emory a very satisfying experience
job_title: Associate Vice President in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Outstanding leaders who were generally very accessible.
Highly inclusive in that there were many opportunities for employees at all levels to generate ideas and/or provide appropriate constructive criticism.
The mission and vision of Emory were a constant mantra and truly guided many decisions and actions.
Good compensation and benefits, especially for a non-profit.  Emory seems to really care about its employees and good home-office balance.
cons: Human Resources department, ironically, was the most difficult department with which to work.  Very difficult to get real live people to answer calls and/or to know with whom one should speak for any given issue.  Once a person was reached, however, they were usually very helpful.

pros: Great Benefits and a highly reputable institute. If one is willing to work for it, it is possible to influence the community.
cons: Inflexible structure disinterested in employee satisfaction and development. Emory suffers from too much money and business and not enough inspiration. They attract some of the best minds by throwing money at them, however these individuals often become isolated as celebrity names rather than adding real quality to the institution. Do not expect to grow here unless you work on developing your self. Mentors are not easily found here.

review_title: Great facilities, great colleagues but moderate salary and not so many future opportunities for graduate student.
pros: The city of Atlanta is a great place to live and has lots of wonderful events going on. The facilities are definitely one of the best in the southeast along with Georgia Tech and UF.
cons: The scientific community and atmosphere here is not as good as prestigious northeast or California schools. The pay is OK but much less competitive than northeast. For science major graduates, there isn't much opportunities around, you have to apply jobs in other places. The culture in Atlanta is kinda layback.

review_title: Remain in control of your career or you will go no where.
pros: Great for networking and good benefits. Thats all I got.
cons: Limited mobility for advancement or career growth and if an employee takes their own career in hand to develop it, provide an encouraging environment to do so. Lack of consistency between departments. Too much red tape and inflated egos which makes for less productivity because you are too busy trying to keep up with the office politics. Lots of veiled racism and discrimination if you have a family and are a minority.

job_title: Senior Business Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Benefits are outstanding!  The company is steadily growing which can lead to advancement and opportunities to learn.   People are very friendly and easy to work with.
cons: The pay scale is low.  HR and Compensation make it extremely difficult to get an adequate raise.  Staff members are extremely suppressed when it comes to pay increases, no bonuses.  Work/Life balance is a joke!

pros:
- If you are looking for predictability  and routine, high education is the way to go! The academic calendar is the same each year, so whatever programming, planning or tasks you have occur around the same time each year. 
-Great medical, dental, and vision benefits.
-Rarely if ever have long hours. This is a job you can not worry about when you clock out.
cons:
- Little opportunities or professional development and/or career investment. The only way that you receive these opportunities is if your supervisor is invested in your professional development. 
-While the benefits are great, the pay is below average. Atlanta is becoming more expensive to live in, yet the yearly raises do not match the rate of inflation in Atlanta. 
-You have to pay for parking. Granted its pre-tax, but still...

review_title: Love my job, love our mission
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: 401k contribution and matching is very generous (6% max from Emory with another 3% if employee contributes 2%), they have been very supportive during the COVID crisis with flexible work arrangements (truly above and beyond - my employer has already shared I will be teleworking until December 31, 2020)
cons: internal promotions don't yield the same salary boosts that they might in other companies, some employees will find a job somewhere else for 1-3 years and then return as an external candidate to see a better realization of salary potential related to increased experience or additional education

review_title: For biomedical researchers, Atlanta is a bigger problem than Emory itself.
pros: The campus is safe when compared to many medical campus in big cities. Good medical insurance.
cons:
(1)Postdocs get salaries below the NIH suggested levels. 
(2)Atlanta is very isolated in the southeast, so the quality of the biomedical research seminars at Emory fall far below its peers on the coasts.  And it's almost a desert for biotech/pharma industry, so when most companies tend to hire from local candidates, a postdoc from Emory stands much less chance than a postdoc from Boston. 
(3) Your life quality depends on your PI. You may be lucky to enjoy your life, or you may be pushed towards the end of your nerves. Alternatives are much harder to find when you're confined in Atlanta where resources are scarce.

review_title: Research is great, benefits lag for students
pros: Great research community in the life sciences. Access to facilities, equipment, and collaborating faculty is superb. Actual research experience depends a lot on your PI but the university environment is excellent and funding agencies will adjust scores accordingly when they review your grant applications. Stipends in life science are good given relatively low cost of living in Atlanta.
cons: PhD student benefits have gotten worse every single year in terms of health insurance: no more vision, no more dental, no more adding dependents to your health insurance. Also no childcare benefits for PhD students with kids.

review_title: long-term commitment that will probably not be worth it
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Atlanta, GA
pros: flexibility in schedule, access to campus resources and data-bases, access to incredible campus pool, community of smart people
cons: Until recently the graduate student stipend was barely enough to live on, the 10-hour rule limited how much you could work to support yourself. Ph.D programs in general are a bad idea since there are far fewer jobs than Ph.Ds.

review_title: Great if you want free education for your kids!
job_title: Senior Technical Project Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: Emory is a very relaxed environment.  Sometimes too much so, but it may be a good fit for you if that's what you're looking for.  Excellent benefits package, with 6% matching, 3% even without employee contribution.  Nearly free graduate level education for employees. Subsidized child care.
cons: Pace... It may be a plus for some, but didn't work well for me.  Slow adoption of latest technologies.  (The university is still using ColdFusion in 2k11.)  Difficult to get promotions because people simply do not leave.

review_title: Stay For A Short Time..... Then Leave!
pros:
Experience getting good work

Flexible schedules (work from home, vacation and sick leave)
cons:
Low salaries. The salaries are beyond low. They try to say that they offer competitive salaries, but they don't. Even HR will tell you that their salaries are too low. 

HR is there for management and Emory. They can't be trusted 

Management shows favoritism and they will block you if you try to get another job. 

You're stuck in a job once you have it. No room for promotion unless you go to another department

pros: Amazing resources and opportunities to collaborate departmentally. Benefits are amazing and the work is interesting and challenging. The culture on campus is vibrant, young and always great speakers, exhibits . . . to be a part of.
cons: Though the students have amazing IQ's, sometimes I feel they lack EQ - and I wish there was more of a professional development program to help them value the work of Emory's staff. Not a lot of room for advancement.

review_title: Great benefits, but overall not a lot of room for growth
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Benefits are the best--health insurance, tuition reimbursement, retirement plan
Work-life balance is great--they do allow for flexible time to take classes, etc.
Company values are in line with giving good care to people--intrinsic values
Quality facilities--campus is always being updated/renovated
cons:
Pay--generally lower than most other places for a lateral position
Hard to get a raise
Interview process is nonexistent and they should implement one to hire more qualified people
Difficult to fire underqualified people

job_title: Director of Annual Giving and Alumni Relations in Atlanta, GA
pros: Emory offers a great deal of flexibility and alternative work arrangements (work from home, telecommute, etc.). Benefits are good, especially the employee courtesy scholarship. I was able to get my MBA while working at the school for far less than out of pocket than what I would have paid without it.
cons: The pay isn't the best. It could be more competitive with other schools in the area. There is a need to lay out clearer career paths so that people know how they can advance their careers without having to leave.

pros: The accessible resources and experienced faculty are abound.  So many brilliant minds and helpful souls, to tap into.  No wonder they consider this school the ivy league of the South! Plus the stipend is very competitive nationally, as the cost of living in Atlanta is comparatively quite low.
cons: Throughout my graduate school experience, the faculty are predominately biased toward their students pursuing academic roles upon completion.  However, the graduate school for biomedical sciences (GDBBS) is working towards providing resources for other outlets, which caters to students pursuing other career avenues.

review_title: Could be a great place to work, but management make it hard for those in support positions
pros: Excellent environment as far as higher education is concerned. You are in the midst of innovation in every field. If you are with a team that promotes a fair and valuable work environment, you will enjoy this place.
cons: It is still not fair and equitable. There are still some discriminatory systems in place. If you are an employee who has a problem with management, there is no recourse unless the treatment is blatant.

pros: Flexibility and decent work-life balance.  Depending on the department, the experience can be really great.  Also, Emory is a large organization with two business units (the University and the Healthcare side), which can offer many opportunities for advancement.
cons: Emory is very large.  Depending on the department's inclusion in some of the university-wide initiatives, an employee can miss out on some opportunities.  The benefits are horrible.

review_title: Good resources, low pay, long hours
pros: The University itself has good resources.
cons: Paying to park at work, underpaid work in science labs, difficult to use time off, the senior researcher in charge of your lab basically owns you and is allowed significant leeway to set their own rules.  I was constantly pressured to work off the clock and on holidays.  However, I got the feeling that the experience is very dependent upon who you work for and not universal across all research labs.  Also, in spite of regular University-wide emphasis on safety, enforcement of this in the office is very lax.

job_title: Research Project Coordinator, Senior in Atlanta, GA
pros: Love the diversity. Great to work with (mostly) smart people. Lots of opportunities to learn and develop if you take the initiative. So much is done to keep college students happy that staff can feel ignored or like second class citizens.
cons: Felt underpaid and under-appreciated. Administration disconnected from staff. No support from HR even though my position was eliminated due to lack of funding which is contrary to their own policies.

review_title: One of the largest employers in Atlanta
pros: I am lucky to live nearby.  Compensation is pretty good and the faculty/staff (for the most part) are good to work with.
cons: Traffic and the cost of parking.  The shuttle services could certainly be improved.  It is a very large organization, very easy to get lost and unsure of how you fit in.  Why is coffee so expensive?  Logic is not something usually practiced here.

pros: Depending on your lab, can be a very flexible work environment, as long as the work gets done. The more ambitious people in these positions don't tend to stick around too long- either med school or grad school or something else. Good benefits and vacation policy.
cons: HR is notoriously stingy and you really have to fight for pay increases. They will try and start you as low as possible and usually annual raises barely keep up with inflation. Your real chance for a pay hike it a change in job title- ask for it when it makes sense strategically.

review_title: Benefits make up for the salary deficits
pros: I loved working at Emory.  As a university it’s an environment that encourages self growth, both personal and professional. It allowed me to be part of a community that is diverse but is highly goal oriented. Although, the salary was minimal, I stayed longer than I expected because I truelly loved my job there.
cons: Salary is lower than the avg but the benefits make up for it.

review_title: Good Experience if you can navigate the politics
pros: It gives you lots of experience and they have a good reputation.
cons:
The culture is one that puts alot of pressure on students, faculty and staff.
It is very HR heavy.  Nobody is encouraged to solve problems before they escalate, so folks always run to HR putting strain on the environment.

review_title: Good environment for biological sciences graduate students
pros: Lots of cross-discipline collaborations, environment is friendly (not extremely cut-throat), PIs and labs generously share equipment, reagents etc. Many programs built in for alternative careers (non-academic) support including teaching fellowships, translational science programs, patent law internships, science writing etc. Progressive campus with emphasis on being "green".
cons: Typical university bureaucracy can be annoying when trying to do the simplest things like submitting reimbursements. Graduate students get very minimal health care at Student Health which is not much better than googling your symptoms. No dental or vision care. Parking is very expensive and public transport can be difficult depending on where you live.

review_title: It all depends on who you work for
pros: Benefits are decent, not amazing though. Pay is pretty good for the educational industry. If you have kids and can put in 10 years they get tuition paid in full. Retirement contributions are pretty good.
cons: Your boss defines your work experience. It can really change drastically boss to boss. Raises have been 0 or near zero for several years now.

review_title: Very supportive and flexible work study job with a great team.
job_title: Student Circulation Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros:
- flexible hours that are scheduled around your classes
- great circulation team
- quiet workspace
- in the evenings, often downtime at the desk where you can (unofficially and sneakily) do some work (but don't get caught!)
- they covered the cost of hours that I worked beyond my work study allotment, which most work study positions won't do
cons:
- midterm and finals season is MISERABLE because everyone's in the library much more and checking things in and out like mad
- the team changes often since most of us are student workers who are graduating at different rates

pros: I really liked the way students, residents, and fellows are treated at Emory - with utmost respect. This is not the case in some other universities where professors don't even say 'hi' to you. Benefits are good, especially starting your second year. Campus is just gorgeous, it's a pleasure to go for a walk for lunch.
cons: Since CDC is right around the corner, you get people going to two major organizations at once. Traffic on Clifton can get pretty bad in the morning and around 5 pm. That was pretty much the only bad thing.

review_title: Double Emory Alum...job "eliminated" when I was 7 months pregnant
job_title: Associate Program Director in Atlanta, GA
pros: Interesting research and feeling like you are contributing to society.
cons: Emory is still very much an "old boys' club" with completely different benefits and status for non-professor professionals.  Low pay, extremely political and not a good place for working mothers.  Emory offers no paid leave for regular employees.  You can apply for short term disability but if you have any underlying medical conditions you will be turned down.

review_title: Emory University is a pretty good place to work for, except the Call Center which is like a Hungarian sweat shop!
pros:
- Training
- The Name
- Location
- Pay is OK for a job in my field
- Opportunities to participate in Focus Groups and Forums
cons:
- Tuition reimbursement is at 5%
- UTS attendance policy is antiquated and does not allow for a work/life balance
- Calculation for vacation days is very "tight"
- No personal business days

review_title: Was a great job until Emory became "big business"
pros: Great range of work including education, healthcare, and research- exposure to many different kinds of networks- LAN, WANS, wireless, and DAS.  Great coworkers.
cons: Emory deciding to go "big business" created so much bureaucracy and paperwork that you can no longer get things done in a timely manner.  Upper management does not believe in transparency- coworkers were dismissed  after being told "don't worry, we are not letting people go"

review_title: Team oriented, great place to work
pros: Great place for collaborations.  Atlanta is a great place to live.  The campus is beautiful.  Many people have worked at the CDC and it is easier to network and find a job there if you are looking to go that route
cons: It is very much a business and the school is always trying to get your money.  Parking costs $654 for the year and parking tickes cost between $50 and $150 dollars!

review_title: Excellent Experience for Future Sales Work
pros: The working atmosphere makes up for the drudgery of cold-calling for hours on end.  With a self-motivating personality there is ample opportunity for raises and bonuses.
cons: The opportunities for promotion are very limited.  The raise structure is very rigid, with little allotment for subjective review of performance; luck factors into success far too heavily.

pros: This is a great highly ranked private research university.  Opportunities are here for motivated people; top leadership is great, well intended, fair, and genuine.  If you are coming here to loaf and lead the entitled life, don't; this is a place that expects commitment and performance
cons: It is a large organization, so if you like small employers, this might not be the place for you.It is in Atlanta, and traffic is an issue for commuters.

pros:
Emory University is an excellent academic institution to work for. What I value and appreciate most about this school are the following qualities.
Resource rich
Challenging 
diverse
rigorous
cons: Leadership does not always consult with students or department heads when making drastic changes. For example, in the fall of 2012 the university cut 5 graduate programs (giving the students 5 years to graduate or transfer to a different department) with no warning or explanation

review_title: Wonderful experience full of opportunities in career advancement and personal growth.
job_title: Senior Research Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Emory is top tier university in great city with competitive cost of living. Emory offers great salary and benefits package. In addition, tuition benefits for staff and faculty are tremendous, offering massive discount on coursework for those pursuing a degree.
cons: Typical 9-5 office environment can be boring in many of the positions. Traffic is horrible around the campus, and parking can be annoying.

pros: Great benefits, relaxed atmosphere. Surrounded by forward thinking academics and talented healthcare leaders. There is no shortage of motivated thinkers. Also continually refreshing to work with learners and new Drs.
cons: Sometimes political, but no more than any other company. Some times red tape can get in the way of real progress. Strong performers are not always held accountable for less than cordial interactions with others.

pros: Work Life balance and flexiblity by management is great.  Stability is a plus and the benefits are reasonable.  The opportunity to become involved in the general Emory Community is abundent and recommended by management.
cons: Not much room for advancement in my current role. The salaries could be a little more competitive.  Employees should be charge lower parking rates which is a very heated topic among staff and faculty.

review_title: High RN turnover, low RN morale, stressed out dept managers, lavishly compensated Sr executives
pros: Apparently the "prestige" of working at Emory should be enough. Hmmm. That didn't help me pay my bills.
cons: Crappy pay. Slowly chipping away at the benefits that used to compensate for said crappy pay.

pros: The Office provides much room for creativity in developing new ways to market the University to prospective students. You will look at other competitive marketing strategies.
cons: They are unclear about the expectations of the job and punish employees for following instructions from their supervisors. They hire without knowing precisely what they want and it takes a toll on the quality of the job.

pros: Benefits package is comprehensive, but, individual benefits can be underwhelming. You can't get credit for tuition reimbursed classes, and the HSA plan has an increasing number of employer contributions gated behind bullcrap health incentives (e.g., you get $100 if you participate in a series of conference calls about weight loss). They still cover all the bases, though. 8/10 overall.
cons:
In my office, there was an entrenched group of managers that had lost touch with the office's purpose and refused to retire. 

Transportation along the Clifton Corridor is terrible.

There was no regular performance review.

pros: Highly professional environment with employees who care. Work with students, staff and faculty on a daily basis. The University offers free tuition for employees and their families
cons: Expectations are always high, so you have to stay on your game, have a good attitude and present well. Good pay but you earn it.

pros: Great place for research very advanced! Great benefits!
cons: If you do not have PhD you will be always treated as a second tier researcher despite of the amount of publications you have. Most of the PI do not have any managerial experience as a result treat you as ... Again it is great place for polishing your resume with publications and experience but not with professional growth.

pros: It is a great experience, met a lot of cool people who were all interested in learning about me and help me mature in this job.
cons: Sometimes, the students are pretty rowdy and hard to keep in  control. This is only some of the time, though, but it is something to keep in mind. Additionally, it isn't perfectly organized/scheduled.

pros: Has a strong orientation to sustainability and commitment to the community
cons:
You can easily get stuck with a poor manager; there is no room for 360 degree feedback.
If you are paid by a grant, you are likely to get paid way off scale, at a fraction of what the salary scale is for your field.

review_title: A great place to plateau- if you want your skills to grow but your title and responsibilities to stagnate.
job_title: Research Informatics Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: Job stability, telecommuting, working with very intelligent principal investigators (researchers)
cons: Huge organization type mentality, little innovation, risk averse, anti-capitalist, a dean's word is worth more than gold (or all the human reason in the world)

pros: good pay and good resources for staff on campus.  free software and training.  Happy people and smart, great students who are easy to work with and teach.
cons: the school often pretends to have procedures in place, which are not as firm or relied upon as they suggest they are. They also believe themselves to be better trained and more up-to-date as than they actually are.

review_title: Emory University really values its employees.
pros: They offer rather decent health benefits. Additionally, the environment is wonderful, and there is a real rapport amongst coworkers. Employees also get access to the wonderful facilities that the campus has to offer, such as the main library and the gym.
cons: I have noticed that the employees that work in maintenance and in the food service departments do not seem to receive as much immediate consideration either from students or administration. Applying to work at the University is a long process as HR is very slow-moving.

job_title: Research Postdoctoral Fellow in Atlanta, GA
pros: There are a lot of career development, grant writing, and networking resources available to postdocs. The university uses the NIH pay scale and they cover your insurance. If you are a long term employee (15+ yrs I think) your kids can go there for free/discounted tuition.
cons: The insurance is less than stellar. You have to use Emory clinics to get the most out of your coverage and it is difficult to get appointments. Pretty much anything other than Emory is out of network.

pros: Great facilities, strong professors and students, exciting place for science research. Atlanta is a great city to live in, too. The school attracts well-known academic speakers and is a good place for networking.
cons: Bloated administration is sapping school monetary resources. Administration does not respond to or even consider student and faculty needs. Relations between faculty and admin are strained as a result. The school also contracts out food services to a company which has a track record of violating worker rights.

review_title: Good work for students who want a part time job.
pros:
Pay, proximity for students, flexible hours. I was able to work whenever I wanted during business hours, with or without anyone else present. Responsibility was given to me for finishing my tasks.
It was relatively easy encoding work, and I was praised for what I thought was average performance. (Which could be a positive or negative.)
cons: Repetitive, boring, etc. Not much variety.

pros: Located in great part of Atlanta.  Strong brand locally, nationally and globally.
cons: Mircomanagement environment.  Like to 'fire people for fun' because people have way too much time on their hands and spend time harassing and picking on others during the course of the work day. Department operate in silos and office politics are alive and well.  Emory still has  that 'good ole boy' mentality operating in management.

pros: Higher than average wages for entry level student affairs salaries, more diversity than many institutions, women of color are the backbone of Campus Life
cons: Women of color are gaslighted, manipulated, and not given well-deserved promotions in Campus Life, promotions appointed to leadership's "favorites," Emory talks a good game regarding social justice but don't actually care about it.

review_title: Good university, but I did not have a good experience
job_title: Post Doctoral Research Fellow in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great location, good size, lots of access to interesting events
cons:
I was not a good fit for the research lab I was in.  While others seemed to be happy sitting silently at their cubicles all day, I felt like I needed more communication and collaboration with peers.

My supervisor was also rather disengaged, and in general it seemed that nobody had any passion for what they were doing.  I decided to leave because it was a depressing work environment.

review_title: So far so good..but could be better
job_title: Senior Research Interviewer in Marietta, GA
pros:
- Great Supervisors who do not micromanage employees and allow us to create our own work flow for the day. 
- Good benefits (403b Basic contribution + Match, medical/dental/vision coverage).
- Courtesy scholarship for classes taken at Emory.
- PTO and Sick leave (although it takes a while to accrue).
cons:
- Little room to move up within research departments with other staff members with similar experience.
- Underpaid for position (taking into consideration work experience and degrees).
- Little involvement with PI's and their research staff.

pros:
Smart colleagues
Great facility
Energetic campus environment
New Dean
Good reputation
cons: Faculty/staff caste system - an extremely political, crony system. Run by a handful of senior, tenured faculty. Form more important than function - a lot of the people with new ideas for tackling old issues do not get support. Need more diversity of gender, race and age among the faculty.

review_title: You have to make your own path
pros: The benefits are pretty good, especially the tuition coverage you receive.  I have been able to get a graduate degree while working here, which was my goal.
cons: The salary is pretty low and strictly tied to HR structure policies.  I have also found there is little room for advancement, and many people have been in the same positions for years.

pros: The educational benefits are excellent. Most departments seem concerned about the employee and work/life balance more than others. Laid back workplace, for the most part.
cons: Stay out of SOM unless you are upper administration. Internal functions are often outsouced, which can get frustrating. Also, paying to park can be quite expensive.

pros:
Really good benefit including health insurance and 401K. 
Perfect experimental supporting system, including various instruments, and perfect management system. 
Good work life balance
cons:
Crowded working place. Too many people working in the same room with a lot of instruments. More than 4 lab share just 1 lab.
The salary is low, and increase slowly.

pros: Good benefits overall, strong commitment to diversity & social justice, competitive salary, opportunities for advancement, strong support for professional development
cons: Work life balance can be tough at times; work day schedules can be somewhat inflexible;  while salaries are competitive, annual raise pools are more limited; parental leave policies on the university side are a bit antiquated & do not truly support parents taking a full 12 week FMLA leave

review_title: Top-tier research institution with great community and resources
pros: Great community and plenty of resources for those willing to seek them out, lots of networking opportunities, Emory invests in your retirement which is not a given for all top-tier research institutions, extensive and affordable benefits
cons: Postdoc appointments at medical school end at 5 years (use your time wisely!), salaries are not the best for scientists and non scientists alike, same challenges you would find at other academic organizations and important to find the right environment for your professional development

pros: Prestige is an important factor in continuing with this position. Often, I observe the administration supporting staff, and I have a great deal of job flexibility.
cons: There is some pension to make simple tasks overly bureaucratic and somewhat drawn out. Lots of paperwork for very simple things.

job_title: Assistant Program Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Every department I've transferred to has gotten better and better over the years.  Very stable and reliable company to work for. Most departments value their employees.
cons: Executives look at employees, sometimes, as disposable people when they have complaints.  It seems as though the first thing they decide to do when an employee has issues with their manager is get rid of the employee and not the manager.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Amazing flexibility and mentorship from leaders in the industry. While the pay was low, it really opened doors for me for jobs after I graduated.
cons: Pay was low as only a graduate research assistant. My manager was quite disorganized at times, which was why I decided not to take a full time job after graduating.

review_title: Small team. But very nice people to work with. One of the best university work environments
pros: cooworkers are very friendly. Nearly no overtime. excellent work-life balance.
cons: Not very good for technical grow since the group is small and their knowledge level is limited. There's almost no processes either. People are dedicated. However, they are more skilled craftmen other than well organized efficient team.

review_title: Decent salary, great benefits, it really depends on what lab you get in.  Often upper management isn't earned.
job_title: Research Project Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits, lots of research opportunities.  There is a lot of horizontal mobility across the University.
cons: Byzantine command structure, stagnant salary.  Managers are PhDs and MDs who have grant money, so they often do not know how to treat employees well or communicate effectively.

review_title: A nice place but not suitable for enginners
pros:
1. Work life balance
2. Flexible working schedule
3. Mostly are nice and smart researcher
cons:
1. Very old technology, career path is blurred, supervisor is not responsible for your career growth, the dean of department is not interested on engineers.
2. Research based institute, people only care for data but don't care for system design, no matter good or bad.

review_title: Decent place to work, as far as post-docs go
pros: Emory has a nice campus, the people are pretty friendly, and the work is interesting (depending on what sort of work you do here...as a researcher, I find my work to be interesting)
cons: The pay, as a post-doc, is very low compared to what I would be making if I had a job in industry

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Depending on the department, you can have other options to continue your growth. My current team is a nice group of people who make the job a lot more easier.
cons: Sometimes their can be some favoritism but overall I have no complaints. I could say Emory under pays their employees based on my research with other companies and other people I know that work outside of Emory.

review_title: Graduate students do the work of employees
pros: Emory University is a great academic institution with a thriving community of medical professionals and research experts.
cons: As a graduate student, the numerous employee benefits do not apply. While the system has gotten better, you may feel like a second class employee.

job_title: Research Specialist; Senior in Atlanta, GA
pros: The benefits are great. The salary is very competitive for the type of work it is. Emory doesn't seem to have any of the corruption issues that other research institutions and hospitals do.
cons: I find myself constantly training and managing people that have more advanced degrees than I do, but this is not uncommon for biomedical research is the South and cities similar to Atlanta.

pros: You'll get a lot of research experience here, if you plan to work in medical or public health field. All of the professors are nice and knowledgable. You'll also get an opportunity to broad your networking.
cons: You may feel bored of your work, if you can't get the chance to work with the environment outside the university.

pros: Great benefits for all staff.  403(b) plan matches 9% for 2% employee contribution.  Great location in suburban Atlanta.  Great place to work.
cons: Difficult to find negatives, although traffic can be tough at peak commuting times.  There are limited roads into and out of the area so there can be a bottleneck effect.

review_title: Great opportunity to learn - No opportunity for career growth
pros:
401k matching
401k vesting
PTO
Passionate/Dedicated employees
that is all...
cons:
Senior Management is not ethnically or gender diverse - AT ALL
Career Advancement not available outside of Tenure track
Professional Development discouraged
High turnover in middle management within university and healthcare

review_title: It's okay if you just want to be average.
pros:
It's a prestigious university.
Benefits are about average
Employer match for 401k is fantastic, but requires you to stay for a long duration.
cons:
Pay isn't great. 
You have to pay for your own parking, which is ~700/yr 
It's a university, so there is only so much you can move around as far as career growth.

pros: A very laid back, flexible work environment.  The faulty and staff are great. Great "courtesy" scholarship package
cons: Big egos to deal with once in a while, pay could be better and "Why" do you pay to park to come to work...nonsense to many!!!

pros: this is a really good position i really enjoyed working on the floor and ensuring that my customers were satisfied and happy
cons: t was fast pace half the time you had to stay moving and ensuring that everything was in place at all times and keeping to the time schedule to

pros: Excellent flexibility in work schedules and telecommute options as a whole, but this can vary within departments. Excellent insurance, though you have to pay a lot more to cover a spouse who can be covered by their own employer. Very good 401K match. Generally a stable environment.
cons: Very limited salary growth over time, with limitations on salary increases even when moving from one position to a higher position. A high degree of bureaucracy within the university.

pros: Atlanta is a nice city to live in.  It is relatively easy to recruit people to Emory, albiet not superstars.
cons: Emory medicine has slipped.  It is in need of new leadership and vision.  The current culture is that of mediocrity.

pros: I love working at Emory because you are working at an institution that strives to be the best and everything they do. They value liberal arts in addition to medicine. There seems to be excitement throughout the staff about their work.
cons: It can be pretty PC at times.

pros: Very supportinve environment.  I greatly enjoyed my time at Emory University.  Benefits are fantastic and it is great to support such a great organization
cons: Pay is extremely low in Human Resources.  Officer level Management is not always supportive of new initiatives or going the extra mile.

review_title: I was a student assistant as a work-study student. Great experience
pros: Overall great environment, they hire the very best because it is such an esteemed institution. Very understanding of the work/ school balance and willing to work around it
cons: Compensation was low, but what do you expect? You're a student assistant. Sometimes I wished I could work more hours, but it's hard to get that due to department budget constraints

review_title: Comfortable job, but not much room for promotion.
pros: Solid pay, regular and flexible hours, very nice benefits. Hourly employees are also eligible for overtime pay. Nice place to work for recent college grads.
cons: Employees must pay a fairly hefty monthly parking fee. Not much room for upward mobility, at least without a higher degree.

pros: World renown research, excellence in teaching, flexible academic environment, cheap city living, excellent collaborative research environment, not an ivory tower.
cons: Impossible administration. Burgeoning admin numbers are wasting money and impeding the staff and faculty from doing their jobs. Expensive administrators are choking the institution.

review_title: I couldn't image a better place to work
job_title: Full Time Faculty in Atlanta, GA
pros: Emory is, first of all, a principle-driven place: ethics is not an option at Emory, and the effort for diversity engagement is commendable. Attention to students if high, and the location/organization of the Campus is fantastic.
cons: Not many: the effort for cross-pollination among Department is already apparent, we need it to continue.

review_title: It has been a growing experience
pros: I learned how to take constructive criticism from my superiors. I also learned to deal with rejection in a professional manner.
cons: The supervisors were not always consistent in the manner they delegated their authority to the other callers. It was sometimes blatantly obvious that friendships were more important that effective adminstration.

pros:
learned a lot really a great place to grow and expand the opportunities. 
people are really nice here and are willing to help
cons:
the payment is average i guess due to its a part time job instead of a full time job.

but again, still a great place to start as a student

job_title: Senior Project Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: Very flexible with work life balance.
cons: Do not pay you what you're worth even when management knows it.  Does not increase pay with degrees earned which leaves you open to making the same pay as someone who is entry level.

review_title: A good Gap Job when in between college and graduate School
pros:
-Good way to interact in the field of your interest
-Good Recommendations for School
-Interact people with degrees and career advice
cons:
-Depends on who is heading the research
-You are limited to your job based on your degree
-Only way to go up is to get into school for higher degree
-Really a long time to get into research group were people wait like 6 to 1 year before starting.

pros: Emory University is a high quality private university. It has numerous scientific research resources both in hardware and software. And there are also a lot of opportunities to communicate with other scientists, share scientific ideas.
cons: As a postdoctoral researcher, the salary is low, and the increase of salary is also low. Also, as the university is big, you always need to walk for long time to get the resources you want.

review_title: Fine place to be a graduate student
pros:
health care is great
as graduate programs go the work life balance is ok
most advisers are supportive if you don't want to become a PI
Atlanta is a great city to be in and the campus is nice
cons:
no vision, no dental
department (chemistry) expectations change all the time and vary between divisions 
no recruiters from industry have visited Emory in the past 5 years
no help finding a job after graduation

review_title: Great staff, great pay, great benefits.
pros: There is a friendly staff, good benefits, and they offer competitive pay rates. Emory really tries to take care of its employees.
cons: It is run like a corporation. There is often confusion when one department tries working with another one. Emory tries to be stingy at times.

job_title: Senior Business Manager in Atlanta, GA
pros: This employer prioritizes promotion from within and provides a competitive benefits package, including those for professional development. I was very proud to work there - Emory Healthcare and the graduate academic programs are nationally ranked in the top ten for the nation.
cons: the business/academic units are silos

review_title: Depends on the School in question
job_title: Senior Administrative Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: I loved my coworkers and many of the faculty members- there were some lovely people. The benefits are excellent.
cons: Within my unit, there were no opportunities for advancement. And while the benefits were excellent, the salary was not competitive and did not include cost of living adjustments or meaningful raises over time. Be prepared to job hop if you want a raise.

review_title: Great learning experience but little opportunity for growth in academia (unless you have a Ph.D.)
pros: Great benefits, nice people, nice campus, tuition reimbursement.
cons: Little opportunity for promotion in research, depend on federal funding, salary for research specialist starts at lower than national average.

job_title: Career Ambassador Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Open enviroment, supportive people, great workplace
Lots of career advice as part of the job
Learning enviroment where can feel safe to grow
cons:
Could use a bigger office- there is alot this office serves, but its location makes it hard to find.
Feels slightly under staffed for the whole college

pros: The benefits are excellent for all full and part time employees, even temporary employees get to chime in.
cons: Advancement is not encouraged. Lower level management is just as bad as the upper management is good.

review_title: A good experience, if you are self driven
pros: Emory has fantastic resources both financially and intellectually.  The campus is beautiful and there are myriad opportunities to get involved in projects globally and within the city of Atlanta.
cons: Grade inflation is a huge problem.  Students often feel entitled to an A just for showing up, or handing in the bare minimum.  It is a real disservice to their own education.

pros: Emory is extremely dedicated to the environment, which takes form in an extensive recycling and composting program as well as vegetable/herb/flower gardens and incentives for commute alternatives.
cons: Parking is challenging. The best options are to opt for off-campus parking and take a shuttle to campus, or bike, walk, carpool. But if you need your car to be close to your office, there are long waiting lists for on-campus parking.

pros: Great benefits. A lot of variety.
cons: Type A environment. Working 12 hours a day is expected. Long work hours are not rewarded. No merit increases for top performance. First place I've ever worked and not received a raise for outstanding job performance. Management is allowed to bully employees with no ramifications.

pros: A very collaborative environment for a researcher trying to get some cutting edge research done. Very strong biomedical research and clinical research.
cons: Does not have the same recognition as Harvard or Stanford. The medical insurance benefits for the dependents of graduate students not provided.

pros: great benefits such as the medical, dental, vision; MARTA transportation for employees, educational opportunities for your and your family
cons: no sense of work life balance depending on your department, race matters, and you will not be paid your worth and will be made to feel bad about asking for more money

pros: Free annual MARTA passes, Free Cliff Shuttles, Great Aetna Health PPO packages; discounted rate for pharmacy and Emory-network doctors, free mental health and counseling for employees.
cons: Pediatrics could sponsor more department-wide events to meet people from other labs. Parking is terrible if you don't take the MARTA; all the clinic parking is very expensive.

review_title: Residence Life and Housing is great!
pros: Great benefits, strong teamwork environment, open to receiving feedback, supportive of programming ideas, always able to collaborate with other offices and programs on campus
cons: Can be bureaucratic at times which makes getting a task done a bit more difficult/time-consuming, there is always tons of paperwork which feels like it takes away from completing projects.

pros: Great community, benefits and students!
cons: You have to know someone in order to progress professionally.  Positions are filled without being announced to employees.  Good old boy/girl network in the extreme.

review_title: Managment needs to get out of their own way
pros: Despite mismanagment, the camraderie amongst staff is encouraging.
cons: Employees are not supported by upper management and departmental administration.

review_title: Working for Emory as a lab technician
job_title: Research Specialist Lead in Decatur, GA
pros: Excellent Benefits  Flexible Schedule  Lax work environment, great chance for promotion and advancement,  great environement  friendly people and staff, chilren go to emory for free if you work there
cons: Commute,  congestion,  lunch, based on taxpayer money so grants do run out of money every few years, it is hard to keep steady employment for many years

review_title: My experience at Emory University was an exciting adventure.
pros: The best reasons that I loved working for Emory University was that the students were wonderful, polite and fun to be around.
cons:
The challenges at Emory University were keeping up with the records of every student and the complaints of their financial aid and so on.
I only worked part time and didn't receive any benefits and had a full time workload.

pros: supportive culture, interesting colleagues and programs, university setting .... fairly secure employment if you are contributing well.
cons: issues with work-life balance, parking is limited and transport to campus is mainly car --no real public transport.   not a place that advances people quickly-either in title or salary.

review_title: Be ready to deal with obnoxious professors!
pros: Medical benefits begin almost immediately!!
cons: Please be aware that the professors at Emory University can be rude and very insensitive.  Working conditions can be horrible if that professor is known for bringing grant money into the University -- they are untouchable and can do no harm in the eyes of the University.

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III in Atlanta, GA
pros: Educational environment, clicial expertise, flexibility, constant access to expanding education and learning
cons: low salary, TERRIBLE traffic & parking at the main campus on Clifton Road. Without a PhD or MD, you can only go so far. PhDs are a dime a dozen (one even told me not to bother going to get one)

job_title: Sponsored Research Financial Analyst in Atlanta, GA
pros: Research faculty are the best to work with at Emory, array of federal awards, great experience, learn a lot, great benefits
cons: Lack of diversity in upper management, systematic discrimination of people of color, Emory could do better in overcoming racial discrimination!

pros: Great colleagues, talented faculty, good benefits, nice campus
cons: Poor infrastructure and school-specific services; very amateurish in personnel practices--errors, disorganized.   Faculty who take leadership roles are not held accountable for unit performance.  Cronyism and favoritism of select staff supporting the status quo.

review_title: Phenomenal place for doctoral studies in the biological sciences
pros:
Super collaborative environment between labs
There is a strong, positive work ethic across laboratories
Departments really care about students' interests
The stipend is good, considering it is for students
Opportunities to take classes outside of specialization
Vibrant, friendly campus environment
Professors are always open to meeting up and talking
Healthcare, counseling, career advice, extracurriculars
Availability of job opportunities after graduation
University prestige
cons: I can't think of any cons

pros: nice people. managers were great. very understanding and open to new ideas. Pay was good compared to surrounding offers. Benefits are good especially if you have any desire to stay long term.
cons: Sometimes the traffic can be hectic in the morning. Also, hours can be a bit inflexible. Work space can be filled with college students, which can be a little annoying at times.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: The work load is light; there are a lot of restaurants and fun stuff to do nearby; the people here are very friendly and supportive, especially to international students. There is a large number of international students and employees at Emory.
cons: The salary is not high;

review_title: Too few employees, too much work
pros: Benefits are good, insurance benefits are fantastic.
cons: They are unwilling to hire people to fill openings so work just gets dumped on the ones left. Don't stay too long, or you'll probably lose your job.  If you get hired, learn what you can while there and then leave. They don't care about the staff anymore. We are just cattle.

review_title: Could see my self retiring from here
job_title: Head Golf Coach in Oxford, GA
pros:
Flexible schedule and vast opportunities for professional development and experiential experiences.  Great university from top to bottom. 
Cross-departmental collaboration and easy access to upper administration.
cons: The pay for many positions is below industry average and it can be frustrating considering Emory has near a $10 billion endowment.  Prior experience does not play a large part in salary negotiations.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Atlanta, GA
pros: Good classes, large research budget, name recognition, good stipend and benefits. It was also nice to have the opportunity to teach as a graduate research assistant.
cons: Heavy workload, bureaucracy, preference is given to chemistry and medical students over the other sciences, though possibly for good reason.

review_title: Good place to work if you're looking for stability
job_title: Administrative Assistant, Program in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits, stable, friendly work environment, lots of wellness opportunities, good pay.
cons: Difficult to get ahead if you don't want to stay in your same position, each department/school is very different, moving from one department to another is almost like going to a different company.

review_title: It all depends on your boss
pros: The health benefits are good. Emory is a strong academic institution. There is a lot of good scientific research happening.
cons: As a postdoc here, your lab P.I. has complete power over your hours, work environment, and future opportunities.

pros: Emory University is one of the world's leading research universities. Its mission is to create, preserve, teach and apply knowledge in the service of humanity.
cons: Emory's main campus is located in Druid Hills section of unincorporated DeKalb County, Georgia, a suburban community near Atlanta. Emory’s main campus is about a 15-minute drive from downtown and midtown Atlanta as well as the Buckhead area.

review_title: Great perks; Management overlooks employee morale
pros: Great perks, such as working from home a few days per week.
cons: Leadership doesn’t care about the professional and career development of employees and overlooks employee morale.

pros: Emory University has  a great deal of resources available for scientific research purposes. There was very interesting and exciting research taking place, the various seminar series allow researchers to stay aware of new ideas and results in their fields.
cons: Though the university encourages a collaborative environment within and between departments, the overall environment and attitude at the university was a bit snobbish.

review_title: Great culture, people, and ethics! Working at Emory has been wonderful!"
job_title: Special Events Coordinator in Atlanta, GA
pros: The benefits are endless at Emory. They really strive to take care of employees. The people are wonderful to work with also. It all just depends on the department you get in with!
cons: The salary and raise. They just do not have the funds to keep staff members at a current industry salary.

review_title: Depends on the department you work for
pros:
Excellent benefits for retirement and healthcare
Decent leave 
Interesting work
Great people for the most part
Can have a flexible schedule in some departments
cons:
Can be difficult to advance
MDs will often expect you to work the same hours they work even though you make much less
Flexibility can be excellent but depends on department
Generally salaries are NOT competitive

job_title: Administrative Assistant, Program in Atlanta, GA
pros: Great benefits (even for part time workers), decent salary. Things are different dept to dept, but it is a pretty good place to work in an admin support position.
cons: Not a lot of upward mobility. You kind of get where you fit and stay there.

review_title: Perhaps not reflective of entire institution but not a good experience
pros: Atlanta, resources, gorgeous building, safety measures, park nearby, security, good natural lighting, parking, shuttle service, employee health services, custodial staff does a good job
cons: Management structure is poor, micromanagement, little to no professional development, expected to work 70-80h a week, favoritism, low morale, show-boating

pros: Great and stimulating environment.  Ability to learn new things and the opportunity to be at the frontier of research works.
cons: Not a good place for scientific promotion of potential junior faculty. Traffic is horrible and it can be congested at times.

pros: The pay is decent for what it is (mostly making copies), and I gained some useful academic experience from lightly editing some papers and articles.
cons: The hours varied wildly, and I had to self-report to the university to get paid. This characteristic of the pay system has its advantages, but can also add a layer of stress when combined with studies,

pros: Benefits the best part of the job
cons: toxic employees / managers rule.  Employees spied on, bullied and when employees raise an issue they are labeled difficult, their concerns are ignored causing lack of motivation.  Pigeon holed with no growth opportunities, skills deteriorate and no ability to move to other departments.

pros:
1) Good training support

1) Is an extremely dreary, tele-solicitation job 
2) Can go hours without anyone picking up
3) At least while I was around one couldn't even have a book around you while working

pros: Fair pay, Flexible working hours, opportunities to advance

review_title: Stay away from the clinical trials office
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator III in Atlanta, GA
pros: The CTO manages to recruit outstanding personnel but the overall hostile and chaotic environment lead to high employee turnover.
cons: Extremely heavy workload, little to no support for upper management, too many systems, little cooperation among departments, and non competitive salaries.

review_title: I enjoyed my postdoc at Emory.
job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Atlanta, GA

cons: Commuting options are horrid. Atlanta requires a car to get around and there are only a couple of main roads leading to Emory. Parking is expensive and a 10 minute walk to your lab or office.

pros: Emory IT connection is great. You can use one user name to access all core facilities and IT services. Personnel at research core facilities are generally amazing, very knowledgeable and informative. Research resources are great.
cons: Bureaucratic paper work has been increasing and decreased efficiency of research work. Human resource at department of hematology and medical oncology is utterly unhelpful.

pros: Great scientific opportunity for those coming straight from their bachelor's degree and considering higher education degrees.  Depending on your principal investigator, there are opportunities to be published, go to weekly seminars with guest speakers, and network with senior scientists.
cons: As a entry-level scientist, you're limited to what you can do.  Additionally, you have to clock in/out daily.

pros: Intellectually stimulating, lots of collaborators, great place to be a post doc, lots of career support from the Office of Postdoctoral Education
cons: Salary, but that's for any scientific post-doc, very hard working so you have to set limits for your work-life balance, you are going to have to endure Georgia summers and humidity

review_title: Exceptional growth professionally during my time at Emory.

cons: The commute is long about an hour and a half everyday. The raises are average. Not enough restaurants near North Decatur Building. Parking for employees is not great.

job_title: Client Services Representative I in Atlanta, GA

cons: Traffic getting to the site can be bad.  However, there are no other cons that i can think of.  I would have never left had i live closer.

pros: It is easy to communicate with professor in Emory and you can earn some extra fees during your study in Emory.
cons: The hourly wages are too low for a student and it is impossible to cover the high tuition fees.

review_title: Emory is a world-class research university that is a great place to work.

Collaborative atmosphere
Focus on being a great university
Great infrastructure and resources for students, staff, and faculty
cons:
Traffic
No bike paths 
Cuts to NIH funding are negatively impacting the institution

review_title: Great way of paying PhD Degree

cons: The weak leadership in the fundraising department, and the lack of diversity.

pros: They offer summer fridays at the Alumni Association, which means every other Friday you have off during the summer months. The people who work at Emory are always friendly. Overall it is a pleasant experience

review_title: Great Place to Work as an Undergrad

pros: Wonderful benefits, work-life balance, many opportunities for professional growth, and a great sense of community among faculty, staff, and students.

pros:
Meal plan is included unlike Residential Advisor positions.

cons:
The walkthroughs of the houses can be time consuming
Risk from parties

pros: Social enviornment to help pay student bills, while having positive impact on the community. After class working hours.

review_title: Emory has excellent benefits and job security

HR not willing to help or very slow assisting  employees who want to move into other departments.
